column2: Math for Real: The Top Speed for Humans
column3: How fast can the fastest human run? How long can he or she sustain a top speed? Let’s take a look at the world records in the 100 m, 200 m, and  400 m races.
column5: Math for Real: The Top Speed for Humans

column2: Math for Real: The Top Speed for Humans
column3: 1.  Complete the table at right and calculate the average speed in each race, first by working in meters per second and then in kilometers per hour.
column5: Math for Real: The Top Speed for Humans

column2: Math for Real: The Top Speed for Humans
column3: Alessandra King 2.  According to the table, in which race(s) did a human reach his or her top speed? How do the speeds in the races compare? Why do you think that is the case?  3.  On your own, investigate the average speed for the 800 m, 1600 m, and marathon for 1 year. How do the speeds in the different races compare? What information about human speed and endurance can you determine from this information?
column5: Math for Real: The Top Speed for Humans

column2: Math for Real: The Top Speed for Humans
column3: Edited by Fred Dillon, dillon314@ sbcglobal.net, a math educator from Strongsville, Ohio, and Kevin Dykema, k.dykema@mattawanschool.org, in  Mattawan, Michigan. Manuscripts should show how math is used to solve a real-life problem, preferably in the context of one’s profession, and should be no more than 300 words. Submit manuscripts through http://mtms.msubmit.net.

column2: Math for Real: The Top Speed for Humans
column3: Speed (km/h) 9:58 19:19 43:18 10:49 21:34 47:60 4.  The table gives the average speed  for Usain Bolt and Florence Griffith Joyner in the 100 m. Make a sketch of distance (horizontal axis) versus speed (vertical axis) that shows how you think each individual will run this race and when he or she will reach his or her top speed. Explain.  5.  The top human average speed is  achieved in the 150 m dash, a race that is rarely run. The record for this race is held by Usain Bolt, who ran it in 14.35 s. What is this speed in m/s and km/h?  6.  Apart from Bolt’s times, the other records have been in place for over 15 years. What conclusion(s) can you draw from this information? 7.  These are all average speeds   over given distances. However, speeds recorded for very short bursts (sometimes referred to as  instantaneous rates) can be greater. Research the top recorded speeds. Under what conditions could these numbers have been reached?
column5: Math for Real: The Top Speed for Humans

column2: Math for Real: The Top Speed for Humans
column3: Alessandra King, alessandra.king@ holton-arms.edu, studies mathematics  with her students at the Holton-Arms School in Bethesda, Maryland. She has taught mathematics and physics at the middle school and upper school levels and is interested in creative problem solving, critical thinking, and quantitative reasoning.

column3: Join us in Indianapolis, Richmond, or Houston for NCTM’s 2014 Regional Conferences & Expositions, our signature fall math education events.
